security: This document contains information about a journalist, Tadeusz (Tad) Witold Szulc, suspected of being a hostile foreign agent, including details of his movements, contacts, and alleged anti-Agency activities. Disclosing these details could compromise intelligence-gathering methods, reveal sources of information, and potentially damage relationships with foreign intelligence services. Quoting directly: 'SZULC has been under suspicion as a hostile foreign agent since 1948 when the FBI reported (apparently from a British source) that he was a Communist... It also resulted in continuing watch of his movements and activities because they represented a threat to the cover of Agency personnel.'
summary: A 1977 memorandum details the suspicions surrounding journalist Tadeusz (Tad) Witold Szulc as a potential hostile foreign agent, highlighting his history of contacts with Communist leaders and anti-CIA activities.
summary_one_paragraph: This memorandum, dated February 14, 1977, provides a summary of the long-standing suspicions against Tadeusz (Tad) Witold Szulc (AMCAPE-1), a journalist who became a U.S. citizen in 1954, alleging his connections as a possible hostile foreign agent. It outlines his early suspicion as a Communist in 1948, his frequent contacts with Communist Party leaders in Latin America, and his increasing anti-Agency activities in the 1970s, emphasizing that while no firm conclusions can be drawn, his actions, especially post-Watergate, have been detrimental to the CIA and U.S. image.
title: Tadeusz (Tad) Witold SZULC (AMCAPE-1) (201-50539)
